title: Leopard Print and Pink Transform a “Starter-Pack, White Wall” Living Room
description: Although the homeowner had to compromise on carpet, she was able to completely disguise it with maximalist style. READ MORE...
author: Sarah Everett
excerpt: Although the homeowner had to compromise on carpet, she was able to completely disguise it with maximalist style.
text: Home ProjectsSarah EverettAssistant Editor of Home ProjectsSarah EverettAssistant Editor of Home ProjectsI organize the Before & After series and cover DIY and design. I joined AT in October 2020 as a production assistant. I have an MA in Journalism from the University of Missouri and a BA in Journalism from Belmont University. Past editorial stops include HGTV Magazine, Nashville Arts Magazine, and local magazines in my hometown, Columbia, Missouri.published yesterdayWe independently select these products—if you buy from one of our links, we may earn a commission. All prices were accurate at the time of publishing.About this before & afterU.K.-based homeowner Lois (@colourfulleopard) used the color drenching paint technique in her living room makeover, and she went with a soft whitish pink. “Our biggest challenge by far has been moving from a small, much older property, steeped in character, to a new build,” Lois says. In her house tour, she says this means “moving away from colors and patterns we are familiar with and leaning to more modern colors.”Painting the ceiling was the hardest part. Lois describes the living room’s aesthetic before as “new-build, starter-pack, white wall and gray carpet.” Although she had to live with the gray carpet, she made a major change to the walls and ceiling.“Our proudest DIY has been color drenching our living room,” Lois says. (And the dining room in the home is drenched in the same color, too.) “It was a mammoth task,” Lois adds, “and anyone who has done a big ceiling paint job knows the pain! However, the result is impactful and well worth the effort.” Lois adds on Instagram that she’s since painted the radiator cover pink, too. Lois says that the ballet slipper shade she selected (Farrow & Ball’s Pink Ground) changes color throughout the day and looks almost peachy in the sun. It keeps things light and airy and acts as a neutral, especially given that a leopard print sofa is the star of the show. The leopard print sofa is the focal point, and there are several other leopard details.Two of her other favorite pieces in the room are the large palm lamp — ”she’s giving ’70s Hollywood regency,” according to Lois — and the handpainted ceramic leopard. “We have her right in the middle of the living room for an extra talking point!” Lois says.The floating console doesn’t overwhelm. Lastly, across the room, there’s a compact media console from Homary, a major upgrade from the chrome shelving that was in the showroom and the too-small hairpin-legged piece Lois had right when she moved in. The wall-mount console is nice for hiding cords. It doesn’t take up any floor space so it would be prime for smaller, multipurpose rooms, too, and  it does add an extra surface to style — a bonus for Lois!
html:
• Home Projects

Sarah EverettAssistant Editor of Home Projects

Sarah EverettAssistant Editor of Home Projects

I organize the Before & After series and cover DIY and design. I joined AT in October 2020 as a production assistant. I have an MA in Journalism from the University of Missouri and a BA in Journalism from Belmont University. Past editorial stops include HGTV Magazine, Nashville Arts Magazine, and local magazines in my hometown, Columbia, Missouri.

published yesterday

We independently select these products—if you buy from one of our links, we may earn a commission. All prices were accurate at the time of publishing.

About this before & after

U.K.-based homeowner Lois (@colourfulleopard) used the color drenching paint technique in her living room makeover, and she went with a soft whitish pink. “Our biggest challenge by far has been moving from a small, much older property, steeped in character, to a new build,” Lois says. 

In her house tour, she says this means “moving away from colors and patterns we are familiar with and leaning to more modern colors.”

Painting the ceiling was the hardest part. 

Lois describes the living room’s aesthetic before as “new-build, starter-pack, white wall and gray carpet.” Although she had to live with the gray carpet, she made a major change to the walls and ceiling.

“Our proudest DIY has been color drenching our living room,” Lois says. (And the dining room in the home is drenched in the same color, too.) “It was a mammoth task,” Lois adds, “and anyone who has done a big ceiling paint job knows the pain! However, the result is impactful and well worth the effort.” Lois adds on Instagram that she’s since painted the radiator cover pink, too. 

Lois says that the ballet slipper shade she selected (Farrow & Ball’s Pink Ground) changes color throughout the day and looks almost peachy in the sun. It keeps things light and airy and acts as a neutral, especially given that a leopard print sofa is the star of the show. 

The leopard print sofa is the focal point, and there are several other leopard details.

Two of her other favorite pieces in the room are the large palm lamp — ”she’s giving ’70s Hollywood regency,” according to Lois — and the handpainted ceramic leopard. “We have her right in the middle of the living room for an extra talking point!” Lois says.

The floating console doesn’t overwhelm. 

Lastly, across the room, there’s a compact media console from Homary, a major upgrade from the chrome shelving that was in the showroom and the too-small hairpin-legged piece Lois had right when she moved in. The wall-mount console is nice for hiding cords. It doesn’t take up any floor space so it would be prime for smaller, multipurpose rooms, too, and  it does add an extra surface to style — a bonus for Lois!
